headline: Square Begins Rollout of Bitcoin Payments for Sellers, Targets Full Availability by 2026
summary: Jack Dorsey's Square (XYZ) has begun the rollout of bitcoin payments for merchants on its network. Square began onboarding the first sellers, enabling them to accept Lightning Network-powered BTC payments from customers, Owen Jennings, executive officer at Square's parent company Block (XYZ), posted on X on Tuesday . Payments are settled in real-near time using Bitcoin layer-2 Lightning, with Square processing the exchange into fiat. Square plans to make the service available to all merchants using its sales platform by next year. The company piloted the system at the Bitcoin 2025 conference in Las Vegas in May, allowing attendees to make purchases in BTC by scanning a barcode. Square regards Lightning as fundamental to its plans to accelerate bitcoin payments adoption, which has been hampered historically by slow speeds. Lightning tackles this by creating micropayment channels that can process transaction away from the main Bitcoin blockchain.

headline: Crypto Futures Liquidation: Unpacking the Massive $227 Million Market Meltdown
summary: BitcoinWorld Crypto Futures Liquidation: Unpacking the Massive $227 Million Market Meltdown The cryptocurrency market, known for its rapid shifts and dramatic swings, recently witnessed a startling event that sent ripples through trading desks worldwide. In a mere sixty minutes, an astonishing $227 million worth of crypto futures liquidation swept across major exchanges. This hourly figure alone highlights the intense volatility and the high-stakes nature of leveraged trading in digital assets. Extending this view, the past 24 hours saw an even more staggering $524 million worth of futures liquidated . Such significant events are not just numbers; they represent substantial losses for many traders and offer crucial insights into market dynamics. But what exactly is a crypto futures liquidation, and what does an event of this magnitude tell us about the current state of the crypto market? Understanding Crypto Futures Liquidation: What Just Happened? To grasp the gravity of a crypto futures liquidation , it‚Äôs essential to understand the underlying mechanisms of futures trading in the cryptocurrency space. A futures contract is essentially an agreement to buy or sell a cryptocurrency at a predetermined price on a specified future date. Traders use these contracts to speculate on future price movements without owning the underlying asset directly. The allure, and often the danger, lies in leverage. Leverage allows traders to open positions much larger than their initial capital. For instance, with 10x leverage, a trader can control $10,000 worth of Bitcoin with just $1,000 of their own money. While this amplifies potential profits, it equally magnifies potential losses. When the market moves against a leveraged position, the trader‚Äôs equity (margin) decreases. If this equity falls below a certain threshold ‚Äì known as the maintenance margin ‚Äì the exchange automatically closes the position to prevent further losses for the trader and the exchange. This forced closure is what we call a crypto futures liquidation . The recent event, where $227 million worth of futures were liquidated in just one hour, suggests a sudden and sharp price movement in one direction, catching a large number of leveraged traders off guard. It typically happens when: Sudden Price Swings: An unexpected surge or drop in the price of a major cryptocurrency (like Bitcoin or Ethereum) triggers margin calls for many positions simultaneously. High Leverage: Traders using excessive leverage are more susceptible to liquidation, as even small price movements can wipe out their margin. Cascading Effects: Liquidations can trigger further price drops as large positions are force-sold, creating a domino effect that leads to more liquidations. The Immediate Impact: Analyzing the $227 Million Shockwave The rapid $227 million crypto futures liquidation within an hour, followed by the broader $524 million over 24 hours, indicates a period of extreme market volatility and significant directional pressure. Such a large-scale event points to a few key observations: Unsuspecting Traders Caught Off Guard: A substantial number of traders were likely positioned in the wrong direction, perhaps expecting a rally when the market dumped, or vice versa. This suggests a lack of robust risk management strategies among some participants. Dominant Market Direction: The sheer volume of liquidations in a short period usually signifies a strong, sustained move in one direction. For instance, if the majority of liquidated positions were ‚Äòlong‚Äô (betting on price increase), it implies a sharp price decline. Conversely, if ‚Äòshort‚Äô positions were liquidated, it indicates a sudden price pump. Exacerbated Volatility: Liquidations themselves can intensify market movements. When positions are force-closed, the underlying assets are sold (or bought) on the market, adding to the existing selling (or buying) pressure. This creates a feedback loop, accelerating price changes and leading to more liquidations. This kind of market event serves as a stark reminder of the inherent risks in highly leveraged crypto derivatives trading. It highlights the importance of not only predicting market direction but also understanding the mechanics of how exchanges manage risk and how that impacts individual traders. Why Do Such Massive Crypto Futures Liquidations Occur So Frequently? While the recent crypto futures liquidation event was significant, similar incidents, albeit of varying magnitudes, are not uncommon in the crypto market. Several factors contribute to their frequent occurrence: 1. Unregulated Leverage: Unlike traditional finance, many crypto exchanges offer extremely high leverage options (up to 100x or even more). This allows traders to take on enormous risk with minimal capital, making them highly vulnerable to even minor price fluctuations. 2. 24/7 Market Activity: The crypto market never sleeps. This constant activity means price movements can occur at any time, catching traders off guard, especially those who aren‚Äôt actively monitoring their positions or have insufficient stop-loss orders in place. 3. Market Manipulation and Whale Activity: Large holders (whales) can sometimes execute significant trades that trigger rapid price movements. These ‚Äúwhale‚Äù movements can intentionally or unintentionally trigger a cascade of liquidations, benefiting those who anticipated the move. 4. Emotional Trading: The highly volatile nature of crypto often leads to emotional decision-making. Traders might over-leverage, fail to set stop-losses, or panic-sell/buy, exacerbating their losses during market downturns or missing opportunities during rallies. 5. Lack of Proper Risk Management: Many retail traders, drawn by the promise of quick riches, often overlook or underestimate the importance of robust risk management strategies. This includes not having a clear exit strategy, inadequate position sizing, and neglecting to use tools like stop-loss orders. Navigating the Turbulence: Strategies for Traders Amidst Crypto Futures Liquidation For both seasoned traders and newcomers, understanding how to navigate periods of intense volatility and avoid becoming a victim of a crypto futures liquidation is paramount. Here are actionable insights and strategies: 1. Master Risk Management: This is arguably the most crucial aspect of trading. Before entering any trade, define your maximum acceptable loss. This includes: Position Sizing: Never allocate more than a small percentage (e.g., 1-2%) of your total capital to a single trade. Stop-Loss Orders: Always set a stop-loss order. This automatically closes your position if the price moves against you to a predefined level, limiting your potential losses. Treat it as your safety net. Take-Profit Orders: Similarly, consider setting take-profit orders to secure gains when your target price is reached, preventing potential reversals from eroding your profits. 2. Lower Your Leverage: While high leverage can be tempting, it‚Äôs a double-edged sword. Using lower leverage (e.g., 2x-5x) significantly increases your liquidation price, giving your trade more room to breathe during minor market fluctuations. This dramatically reduces your risk of a sudden crypto futures liquidation . 3. Understand Market Structure and Sentiment: Pay attention to broader market trends, support and resistance levels, and overall sentiment. Are major cryptocurrencies consolidating, breaking out, or breaking down? Understanding the context can help you make more informed decisions about your directional bias. 4. Diversify Your Portfolio (Beyond Futures): Don‚Äôt put all your eggs in one basket. While futures trading can be profitable, consider diversifying your crypto holdings across spot markets, staking, or even different asset classes to mitigate overall portfolio risk. 5. Continuous Learning and Adaptation: The crypto market evolves rapidly. Stay updated on market news, technological advancements, and new trading strategies. Learn from both your successes and your failures, and adapt your approach as market conditions change. 6. Avoid Emotional Trading: Develop a trading plan and stick to it. Emotional decisions, driven by fear of missing out (FOMO) or panic, often lead to poor outcomes. Take breaks, review your strategy objectively, and don‚Äôt chase pumps or dump into panic. The Broader Implications for the Crypto Market Events like the recent crypto futures liquidation of hundreds of millions of dollars have implications beyond individual traders. They can contribute to increased market volatility, sometimes leading to a ‚Äúflush out‚Äù of over-leveraged positions, which can be seen as a market reset. However, repeated large liquidations can also erode investor confidence, attract regulatory scrutiny, and highlight the need for more robust risk management tools and education across the ecosystem. summary: BitcoinWorld Crypto Liquidations Unleash a $113 Million Shockwave in the Market In the fast-paced, often unpredictable world of digital assets, moments of extreme volatility can send a genuine shockwave through the market. Recently, the cryptocurrency community witnessed one such event, with a staggering $113 million worth of futures liquidated in just one hour across major exchanges. This sudden flush was part of an even larger picture: a colossal $409 million worth of futures liquidated over the past 24 hours. Understanding the Mechanics of Crypto Liquidations Before diving deeper into the recent market movements, it‚Äôs crucial to understand the core concept of crypto liquidations . Simply put, a liquidation occurs when a trader‚Äôs leveraged position is forcibly closed by an exchange due to a significant loss. This happens because the trader‚Äôs margin balance (the collateral they put up for their leveraged trade) falls below a certain threshold required to keep the position open. It‚Äôs an automated process designed to prevent a trader‚Äôs losses from exceeding their initial margin and to protect the exchange from potential bad debt. Think of it like this: Leverage: You borrow funds from an exchange to amplify your potential returns. If you have 10x leverage, a $1,000 investment controls $10,000 worth of crypto. Margin: Your initial $1,000 is your margin, acting as collateral. Price Movement: If the market moves against your position, your losses start eating into your margin. Margin Call/Liquidation Price: The exchange calculates a ‚Äòliquidation price‚Äô. If the asset‚Äôs price hits this point, your position is automatically closed to prevent further losses. This mechanism, while a safeguard for exchanges, can be brutal for traders, especially during periods of high volatility. The recent event highlights just how quickly fortunes can turn when trading with leverage. The Recent Shockwave: Numbers Behind the Carnage The numbers from the past 24 hours paint a stark picture of the market‚Äôs recent turbulence. Why Do Such Massive Crypto Liquidations Occur? Massive crypto liquidations are not random events; they are typically the culmination of several factors interacting within a volatile market. The higher the leverage, the smaller the price movement needed to trigger a liquidation. Many traders, seeking quick profits, often over-leverage, making them extremely vulnerable. Market Sentiment and News: Negative news (e.g., regulatory crackdowns, major hacks, economic downturns) or shifts in market sentiment can lead to panic selling, causing prices to tumble rapidly and trigger liquidations. Whale Activity: Large traders or institutions (‚Äòwhales‚Äô) can execute massive trades that significantly impact prices, intentionally or unintentionally triggering a cascade of liquidations. Cascading Liquidations: When one set of liquidations occurs, the forced selling can further depress prices, leading to more liquidations, creating a dangerous feedback loop. This ‚Äòliquidation cascade‚Äô can exacerbate market downturns. Impact on the Crypto Market: A Ripple Effect? When significant crypto liquidations occur, their effects ripple far beyond the individual traders involved. What kind of impact can we expect to see? Increased Volatility: Liquidations often lead to more price swings as forced selling adds downward pressure, or forced buying (in the case of short liquidations) adds upward pressure. Market Sentiment Shift: Large liquidation events can sow fear and uncertainty among traders, leading to a more cautious or bearish outlook in the short term. Reduced Open Interest: The total value of outstanding derivatives contracts (open interest) often decreases after major liquidations, indicating that leveraged positions have been cleared out. Retail Traders: While institutional players also use leverage, retail traders often have smaller capital bases, making them more susceptible to quick margin calls. Traders with Concentrated Positions: Those who put a large portion of their capital into a single highly leveraged trade are at extreme risk if that trade goes sour. Navigating the Volatility: Strategies to Mitigate Risk from Crypto Liquidations Given the inherent volatility and the potential for rapid crypto liquidations , how can traders protect themselves and navigate these turbulent waters? Here are some actionable insights and strategies: Understand Leverage Thoroughly: Don‚Äôt just pick the highest leverage available. A stop-loss order automatically closes your position when the price reaches a predetermined level, limiting your potential losses and preventing liquidation. Set it at a point where you‚Äôre comfortable exiting the trade. Manage Your Position Size: Never risk more than a small percentage of your total trading capital on any single trade. Even if you get liquidated, it shouldn‚Äôt wipe out your entire portfolio. Maintain Sufficient Margin: Keep an eye on your margin ratio. Diversify Your Portfolio: While primarily for spot trading, the principle applies to futures. Don‚Äôt put all your eggs in one basket. If you must trade multiple futures contracts, spread your risk. headline: SEC Set To Shake Up Bitcoin, Ethereum ETFs With In-Kind Approval
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is edging toward a structural makeover of spot‚ÄëBitcoin and Ethereum exchange‚Äëtraded funds, after five Cboe‚ÄØBZX‚Äëlisted products simultaneously asked to swap their cash‚Äëonly creation and redemption model for the in‚Äëkind mechanics long used by commodity and equity ETFs. Filings submitted late on 22‚ÄØJuly cover the ARK‚ÄØ21Shares Bitcoin ETF and the 21Shares Core Ethereum ETF (together in SR‚ÄëCboeBZX‚Äë2025‚Äë010‚ÄØAmendment‚ÄØNo.‚ÄØ3), WisdomTree‚Äôs Bitcoin Fund (SR‚ÄëCboeBZX‚Äë2025‚Äë033‚ÄØAmendment‚ÄØNo.‚ÄØ1) and both the Fidelity Wise Origin Bitcoin Fund and Fidelity Ethereum Fund (SR‚ÄëCboeBZX‚Äë2025‚Äë023‚ÄØAmendment‚ÄØNo.‚ÄØ1). Each amendment rewrites language inserted in early‚Äë2024 approval orders that had locked the trusts into cash creations and redemptions, substituting the phrase ‚Äúcash or in‚Äëkind transactions‚Äù and adding detailed settlement workflows for direct transfers of Bitcoin or Ether between the trust‚Äôs custodian and an authorised participant. Bloomberg ETF analyst James‚ÄØSeyffart, who first spotted the coordinated move, told his followers on X that the quintet of filings is ‚Äúmore positive signs regarding Bitcoin‚ÄØ&‚ÄØEthereum ETFs obtaining the ability to do in‚Äëkind creation and redemption‚Ä¶ This indicates to me that there is positive movement and likely fine‚Äëtuning happening with the SEC.‚Äù Anticipating confusion, he added: ‚ÄúNo, this is not going to be for retail or normies to trade in shares of their ETFs for the underlying asset or vice versa. This would only be for the Authorized Participants (think big wall street firms and market makers) This will make current and future crypto ETFs more efficient. But the vast majority of people won‚Äôt even see a difference because the products on the market now already trade extremely efficiently. This will treat crypto ETPs the same as other ETPs are treated.‚Äù Commenting on a time horizon when retail investors could use the in-kind redemption process, Seyffart added: ‚ÄúWould be cool to see consumers being able to withdraw and deposit actual ETH into the ETF with a certain threshold. I personally think withdrawals like this will eventually happen. But it may be in the distant future. One step at a time. This already exists for some gold ETFs.‚Äù Why In-Kind Matters For Bitcoin And Ether ETFs Under the cash model imposed when spot Bitcoin ETPs were finally approved on 10‚ÄØJanuary‚ÄØ2024, an AP delivers dollars to the fund, which then buys the cryptocurrency in the spot market; redemptions reverse the process. That design solved SEC concerns under Chair Gensler about custody and settlement risk but introduced two frictions: the trust itself must trade in the underlying market, and the resulting order flow can push net asset value away from share price when spot liquidity is thin. In‚Äëkind processing hands those trades back to authorised participants. When creating shares the AP ships Bitcoin or Ether directly to the fund‚Äôs cold‚Äëwallet; when redeeming it receives coins instead of cash. The structure is standard in the broader ETF ecosystem and is associated with tighter spreads, smaller primary‚Äëmarket imbalances and material tax advantages because portfolio securities ‚Äî or in this case, crypto‚Äëassets ‚Äî are released ‚Äúin kind‚Äù rather than being sold and realising capital gains inside the fund. The SEC itself notes that ETFs ‚Äúcan be more tax efficient‚Ä¶ because ETF shares generally are redeemable ‚Äòin‚Äëkind‚Äô. Commodity trusts already employing in‚Äëkind redemptions provide the regulatory template the crypto issuers are invoking. SPDR‚ÄØGold‚ÄØShares, for example, lets an authorised participant exchange a 100,000‚Äëshare basket for physical bullion, a feature that ultimately allows an individual investor to ‚Äútake physical possession of the gold backing his or her shares,‚Äù albeit through a broker‚Äëfacilitated arrangement. By mirroring that language, the Bitcoin and Ether trusts argue they are simply seeking parity with existing commodity ETPs. Operational pressure has also mounted as primary‚Äëmarket volumes grow. Since launch the eleven spot Bitcoin ETFs approved in 2024 have drawn nearly $55 billion in cumulative net inflows; market‚Äëmaking desks face the hurdle of sourcing billions of dollars at 4‚ÄØp.m. every settlement day ‚Äî then unwinding the crypto exposure after the trust purchases coins. This ties up the balance sheet and widens spreads during volatile sessions. Allowing in‚Äëkind hand‚Äëoffs lets desks source or hedge Bitcoin and Ether continuously and deliver the assets straight into the trust‚Äôs wallet at T‚ÄØ+‚ÄØ0. At press time, BTC traded at $118,769.
